awd_titl_txt: CSP4Hawaii: Deployment of Computer Science Principles Courses within Secondary Schools in Hawaii
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Hawaii (UH), in collaboration with the Hawaii Department of Education (HIDoE), will conduct a 3-year study - Computer Science Principles (CSP) for All in Hawaii (CSP4Hawaii) - aimed at improving state-level initiatives to address diversity in computer science education. The project, structured as research-practitioner partnership (RPP), will replicate and study curriculum and teacher professional development for a CSP course, based on previous work by UTeach. It will identify and remediate barriers to participation of underrepresented groups.

The project will collaborate with the University of Texas and their UTeach Professional Development (PD) program to utilize its curated CSP curriculum, best practices, and resources. It will expand teacher knowledge of, and practices with, computer science principles, creating a more diverse pool of classroom teachers who can comfortably integrate CSP coursework into their classrooms to broaden participation. It will use UH faculty, HIDoE high school teachers, UTeach support technicians and industry/business mentors to provide high school teachers with the skills and strategies to improve recruitment and engagement of underrepresented students in CSP and computational problem solving; and it will create Networked Improvement communities (NIC) throughout the State of Hawaii to gather and use meaningful student and teacher demographic information to monitor strategic decision-making for achieving equity of
opportunity for computer science learning.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The University of Hawaii in collaboration with the Hawaii Department of Education (HIDoE), conducted a three-year study - Computer Science Principles (CSP) for All in Hawaii (CSP4Hawaii) aimed at improving state-level initiatives to address diversity in computer science education. The project, structured as a research-practitioner partnership (RPP), involved the replicating and studying of curriculum and teacher professional development for an AP CSP course, based on previous work by UTeach. 

The project has met or exceeded all of its goals. A focus of the project was providing effective teacher professional development that expanded the number of teachers trained to teach AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) in Hawaii. The project has trained 60 teachers from 32 schools on 6 islands. The original project target was 60 teachers from 30 schools. The Hawaii Department of Education is the only state department of education that functions as an entire statewide school district. Seven islands in Hawaii have K-12 public schools but both Lānaʻi and Niʻihau each only have one K-12 school. Thus, according to the Hawaii Department of Education it is very unusual for a project to have this extensive of a reach throughout the islands. 

Key outcomes of the project include:

  • The RPP established an important community of support for participants where they could find answers and felt like valued members of the community. Ninety-five percent of participants felt they had been treated as valuable members of the team. 
  • The teachers valued working with the University of Hawaii, other teachers, and the Hawaii Department of Education as collaborators. Both teachers and the Hawaii Department of Education placed a particular importance on the value of working with the University of Hawaii which would not have been available to them without this grant.
  • The importance of the RPP has helped teachers adapt under extreme conditions from hurricanes to the global COVID-19 pandemic. Ninety-five percent of participants felt that members shared important problems related to teaching AP CSP with the community. 
  • Teachers in the RPP developed new skills and took on new leadership roles.
  • Teachers in the RPP began to use more evidence-based findings to improve their teaching effectiveness.
  • Working together as part of the RPP, teachers were able to make better sense out of their AP CSP scores. By teachers jointly exploring their successes and failures on the AP CSP exam, they have been able to develop more effective strategies for all teachers in the RPP to be more successful.
  • The RPP community has explored various, creative mechanisms for expanding computer science in the state.
  • The findings from the RPP were shared widely with multiple audiences and by various RPP partners.
  • The RPP provided a safe community for teachers to develop new skills and to try new approaches to recruiting diverse students. All teachers (100%) reported that participating in the project had increased their knowledge of AP CSP content and 95% reported that participating in the project increased their knowledge of how to teach to diverse students. 
  • The RPP developed new initiatives during Covid-19 such as forming Girls Who Code clubs.
  • The RPP provides useful insights into effective practices for establishing successful RPPs in other settings.
  • The RPP led to the University of Hawaii accepting the AP CSP exam for course credit.
  • The RPP has laid the groundwork working with the Hawaii Department of Education to establish a computer science requirement for high schools throughout Hawaii. 

This RPP has successfully engaged teachers, researchers, and the Hawaii Department of Education in an effort to expand and diversify computer science education in the state. The project has achieved or exceeded all of its goals. The project has also been an exemplary RPP that has developed teaching, leadership, and research skills in the project participants. Research currently being conducted by the project has the potential to transform computer science education in Hawaii and beyond. 


Last Modified: 10/18/2021
Modified by: Debasis Bhattacharya
por.por_txt_cntn:
The University of Hawaii in collaboration with the Hawaii Department of Education (HIDoE), conducted a three-year study - Computer Science Principles (CSP) for All in Hawaii (CSP4Hawaii) aimed at improving state-level initiatives to address diversity in computer science education. The project, structured as a research-practitioner partnership (RPP), involved the replicating and studying of curriculum and teacher professional development for an AP CSP course, based on previous work by UTeach. 
The project has met or exceeded all of its goals. A focus of the project was providing effective teacher professional development that expanded the number of teachers trained to teach AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) in Hawaii. The project has trained 60 teachers from 32 schools on 6 islands. The original project target was 60 teachers from 30 schools. The Hawaii Department of Education is the only state department of education that functions as an entire statewide school district. Seven islands in Hawaii have K-12 public schools but both Lānaʻi and Niʻihau each only have one K-12 school. Thus, according to the Hawaii Department of Education it is very unusual for a project to have this extensive of a reach throughout the islands. 
Key outcomes of the project include:

 The RPP established an important community of support for participants where they could find answers and felt like valued members of the community. Ninety-five percent of participants felt they had been treated as valuable members of the team. 
The teachers valued working with the University of Hawaii, other teachers, and the Hawaii Department of Education as collaborators. Both teachers and the Hawaii Department of Education placed a particular importance on the value of working with the University of Hawaii which would not have been available to them without this grant.
The importance of the RPP has helped teachers adapt under extreme conditions from hurricanes to the global COVID-19 pandemic. Ninety-five percent of participants felt that members shared important problems related to teaching AP CSP with the community. 
Teachers in the RPP developed new skills and took on new leadership roles.
Teachers in the RPP began to use more evidence-based findings to improve their teaching effectiveness.
Working together as part of the RPP, teachers were able to make better sense out of their AP CSP scores. By teachers jointly exploring their successes and failures on the AP CSP exam, they have been able to develop more effective strategies for all teachers in the RPP to be more successful.
The RPP community has explored various, creative mechanisms for expanding computer science in the state.
The findings from the RPP were shared widely with multiple audiences and by various RPP partners.
The RPP provided a safe community for teachers to develop new skills and to try new approaches to recruiting diverse students. All teachers (100%) reported that participating in the project had increased their knowledge of AP CSP content and 95% reported that participating in the project increased their knowledge of how to teach to diverse students. 
The RPP developed new initiatives during Covid-19 such as forming Girls Who Code clubs.
The RPP provides useful insights into effective practices for establishing successful RPPs in other settings.
The RPP led to the University of Hawaii accepting the AP CSP exam for course credit.
The RPP has laid the groundwork working with the Hawaii Department of Education to establish a computer science requirement for high schools throughout Hawaii. 

 
This RPP has successfully engaged teachers, researchers, and the Hawaii Department of Education in an effort to expand and diversify computer science education in the state. The project has achieved or exceeded all of its goals. The project has also been an exemplary RPP that has developed teaching, leadership, and research skills in the project participants. Research currently being conducted by the project has the potential to transform computer science education in Hawaii and beyond.
